content: The "Biennial Appropriations Act" is cited as the short title. Section 300 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to revise the timetable for the congressional budget process. The timetable for the congressional budget process includes deadlines for the President to submit the budget, the Congressional Budget Office to submit a report, committees to submit views and estimates, Budget Committees to report a concurrent resolution, and Congress to complete action on the budget resolution. Biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill may be addressed by May 15th. On April 15, Congress completes action on the concurrent resolution on the budget. By May 15, biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill may be considered in the House. On June 10, the House Appropriations Committee reports the last appropriation bill to be considered that year. By June 15, Congress completes action on reconciliation legislation. By June 30, the House completes action on biennial appropriation bills. On June 30, the House completes action on biennial appropriation bills to be considered that year, as provided in subsection (b), and the defense appropriation bill. By August 1, Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills to be considered that year, as provided in subsection (b), and the defense. On August 1, Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills to be considered that year, as provided in subsection (b), and the defense appropriation bill. In the case of the first session of Congress following a leap year, with a new President, specific dates will override the usual schedule. The schedule for budget-related actions includes deadlines for the President's budget submission, reports from the Congressional Budget Office, committee submissions, and Congress's completion of the budget resolution. Congress completes action on concurrent resolution on the budget by June 1. Biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill may be considered in the House by July 1. By July 20, the House completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill. Congress finishes action on biennial appropriation bills by August 1. On August 1, Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills, the defense appropriation bill, and reconciliation legislation. On October 1, the fiscal year begins. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Financial Services, Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, Interior, Environment, and Labor, Health and Human Services, Education. In even-numbered years, Congress considers and enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture. Congress shall consider and enact annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture, Commerce, Justice, Science, Energy and Water, Homeland Security, Legislative Branch, and State-Foreign Operations. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET AND IMPOUNDMENT CONTROL ACT OF 1974. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to define "biennium" as a 2-year period starting on October 1. Committee allocations are also adjusted to include appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and the first fiscal year for defense. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and the first fiscal year for defense. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include appropriations for defense and each fiscal year in the biennium. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO TITLE 31, UNITED STATES CODE. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code includes defining 'biennium' and adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code involves adjusting budget submission to Congress for each fiscal year in the biennium and the following 4 years. The budget submission to Congress is amended to cover each fiscal year in the biennium and the subsequent 4 years. This involves adjustments to balance statements, functions, activities, and allowances in Title 31, United States Code. Functions and activities in Title 31, United States Code are amended to cover each fiscal year in the biennium. Allowances for uncontrolled expenditures and tax expenditures are also adjusted accordingly. Section 1105(a)(14) of title 31, United States Code is amended to include each fiscal year in the biennium for budget submission. Section 1105(a)(16) is also updated to cover tax expenditures for each fiscal year in the biennium. Additionally, Section 1105(a)(17) is modified to address future years in the biennium. Section 1105(a)(17) of title 31, United States Code is amended to address future years in the biennium by adjusting the language regarding fiscal years. Section 1105(a)(17) of title 31, United States Code is amended to address future years in the biennium by adjusting the language regarding fiscal years. Prior year outlays and receipts are also amended to reflect the 2 most recently completed fiscal years. Section 1105(a)(19) of title 31, United States Code is amended to reflect the 2 most recently completed fiscal years for prior year receipts. The language is adjusted to refer to those fiscal years instead of specific years. Section 1105(b) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to update estimated expenditures of the Legislative and Judicial Branches to occur every even-numbered year. Section 1105(c) is also amended to provide recommendations to address estimated deficiencies. Section 1105(c) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to address estimated deficiencies by updating recommendations for each fiscal year in the biennium. The text chunk amends sections of title 31, United States Code, to update recommendations for each fiscal year of the biennium and capital investment analysis. SEC. 5. Two-year appropriations; title and style of appropriations acts. Section 105 of title 1, United States Code, is amended to specify the title and style of appropriations Acts for nondefense and defense purposes. Nondefense Acts will have a specific format, while defense Acts will have a different format. The biennium of fiscal years will be specified in Acts making appropriations for defense and government support. The term 'biennium' is defined in this section. The term 'biennium' is defined in this section for Acts making appropriations for defense and government support. Amendments are made to the table of sections for chapter 2 of title 1, United States Code. SEC. 6. MULTIYEAR AUTHORIZATIONS. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include authorizations of appropriations. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years unless no further appropriations are needed. It also delays authorization or revenue bills until the budget resolution and all appropriations bills are completed. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years unless no further appropriations are needed. It also delays authorization or revenue bills until Congress completes action on the budget resolution, all appropriations bills, and reconciliation bills. Exceptions apply to defense, privileged measures, matters in Executive Session, and appropriations or reconciliation bills. Sec. 316 prohibits bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years unless no further appropriations are needed. It delays authorization or revenue bills until Congress completes action on the budget resolution, all appropriations bills, and reconciliation bills. Exceptions apply to defense, privileged measures, matters in Executive Session, and appropriations or reconciliation bills. In years when agency funding is not required under the Congressional Budget Act, the House and Senate committees must hold joint oversight hearings with the Appropriations subcommittees. The hearings will focus on the agency's mission, the impact of biennial budgeting on efficiency, and cost savings associated with it. The hearing required by subsection (a) will review the agency's mission, impact of biennial budgeting on efficiency, cost savings, new programs created, and terminated programs in the off year of the agency budget. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will assess the impact and feasibility of transitioning to a 2-year fiscal period with a biennial budget process. A report on the findings will be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on the Budget within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Act and its amendments will be effective on January 1, 2016, applying to budget resolutions and appropriations for the biennium starting from fiscal year 2017.
